title: Trump's Syria withdrawal leaves Canberra scrambling
text:
The Morrison government has side-stepped questions over whether Donald Trump's abandonment of Kurdish allies in Syria will spark an Islamic State resurgence, while keeping clear of any criticism of the US President.

But Defence Minister Linda Reynolds reiterated that the government would not risk the lives of officials trying to repatriate Australian women and children from detention camps in Syria.

More than 60 Australian women and children are trapped in the camps, set up by Kurdish forces to house foreign fighters and their families. These include those who took up arms for Islamic State.

Senator Reynolds would not be drawn on whether Canberra had been given advanced notice of Mr Trump's surprise announcement that US forces would withdraw from Syria's border region with Turkey.

The withdrawal effectively abandons Kurdish militias who had been western allies in the fight against Islamic State to the threat of a Turkish offensive. However, facing a rare backlash from his own Republican Party, Mr Trump warned Ankara it would face economic sanctions if it moved against the Kurds.

Australia has a complex relationship with the Kurdish people. While the air force in 2014 helped transport arms to Peshmerga fighters in northern Iraq's Kurdistan during early fighting against Islamic State, Canberra has proscribed the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) as a terrorist group since 2005 for its violent campaign for autonomy against Turkey.
description: More than 60 Australian women and children are trapped in the camps, set up by Kurdish forces to house foreign fighters and their families. These include those who took up arms for Islamic State.
